image.altText: A man, woman and infant child stand in front of a house under construction.

items.synopsis: A growing number of Australians are defaulting on their home loans as the number of borrowers at risk of mortgage stress peaks at levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

title.children: 'A perfect storm': New figures reveal extent of mortgage stress ahead of next week's interest rates decision

image.altText: A man in a black shirt sits beside water while a woman in a blue shirt puts her arms around his neck.

items.synopsis: With deteriorating health after four-and-a-half years in Chinese detention, a new diagnosis and lack of treatment could see Australian democracy activist Yang Hengjun die in prison.

title.children: 'If I die … people outside won't know the truth': Australian fears death in Chinese prison after diagnosis

image.altText: A middle-aged man in dark suit speaks at podium in front of Australian and US flags

items.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles says a number of investigations are underway into the crash that killed three US marines on a remote island north of Darwin.

title.children: Rescue turns to recovery after fatal military helicopter crash on the Tiwi Islands

image.altText: Tokyo bedroom

items.synopsis: We challenged four reporters to find somewhere to live for 30 per cent of the average wage in their global cities. From "dorms for adults" to buildings that could be demolished at any moment, they saw it all.

title.children: What does 30pc of average household wage get you on the global rental market?

image.altText: A man in a dark suit leans over a map

items.synopsis: Over the last week focus on the war has been diverted by the plane crash in Russia which is believed to have killed the leader of the Wagner mercenary group Yevgeny Prigozhin, but there are bigger questions, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Fears of a post-Putin Russia have frozen the US

image.altText: Two people in high-vis orange shirts and navy shorts stand in front of a massive mining truck.

items.synopsis: A resources industry veteran says Australia's mining industry has an image problem and many agree with him.

title.children: With a 'dirty' image, WA's mining industry considers how to clean up its act

image.altText: Four people are silhouetted against the backdrop of the moon, which looks massive thanks to a special camera lens

items.synopsis: This week's will be the second full moon we've seen this month. It's going to appear a bit bigger and brighter — but it won't look blue.

title.children: The month will end with a rare supermoon. Here's the best night to see it

image.altText: Eleanor Patterson and Nicola Olyslagers hold Australian flags while flanking Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh

items.synopsis: Eleanor Patterson and Nicola Olyslagers claim silver and bronze in an emotion-charged women's high jump in Budapest, lifting Australia to a best-ever medal haul of six at a world athletics championships.

title.children: Patterson, Olyslagers in the high jump medals as Australia enjoys best-ever world champs haul

image.altText: DSC01732 copy

items.synopsis: Her unconventional approach to surviving in the wild captured the public imagination. Now TV star Gina Chick shares with Australian Story how connecting with nature helped her through unimaginable loss.

title.children: Why Gina Chick says happily ever after is overrated

image.altText: Ange and Robbie thumbnail

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Robbie Williams changes song lyrics to celebrate success of Australian soccer coach. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ange Postecoglou's early success with English soccer side Tottenham has led singer Robbie Williams to re-work one of his songs in the Australian manager's honour. In his first three weeks of the Premier League season, Postecoglou has Spurs sitting third with two wins and a draw. His style of play has won over the Tottenham fans, who have started singing his name in the stands. One of the songs is a version of Robbie Williams' Angels and the singer has appeared on Instagram giving it his official approval. Take a listen below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Robbie Williams joins Spurs' love for  'Big Ange'

children.content: Ange Postecoglou's early success with English soccer side Tottenham has led singer Robbie Williams to re-work one of his songs in the Australian manager's honour.
In his first three weeks of the Premier League season, Postecoglou has Spurs sitting third with two wins and a draw.
His style of play has won over the Tottenham fans, who have started singing his name in the stands.
One of the songs is a version of Robbie Williams' Angels and the singer has appeared on Instagram giving it his official approval.
Take a listen below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will travel to Adelaide on Wednesday to announce the date for the Voice to Parliament referendum. Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo told ABC News Breakfast they had almost 30,000 volunteers working towards a Yes vote. "There's around 30 to 40% of Australians that haven't made up their minds yet and those are the people that we'll be focusing on," he said. When asked whether he was worried the Yes campaign may get a majority of votes nationally but not the majority of states, Mayo said the Yes campaign was focusing on speaking to all Australians. "We're not taking any state for granted. "We're not writing off any states, not Queensland, not WA."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yes campaign 'not taking any state for granted'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will travel to Adelaide on Wednesday to announce the date for the Voice to Parliament referendum.
Thomas Mayo
(ABC)
Yes campaigner Thomas Mayo told ABC News Breakfast they had
almost 30,000 volunteers working towards a Yes vote.
"There's around 30 to 40% of Australians that haven't made
up their minds yet and those are the people that we'll be focusing on," he said.
When asked whether he was worried the Yes campaign may get a majority of votes nationally but not the majority of states, Mayo said the Yes campaign was focusing on speaking to all Australians.
"We're not taking any state for granted.
"We're not writing off any states, not Queensland,
not WA."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A cruise ship has collided with a petrol tanker off the Spanish tourist island of Mallorca. P & O Cruises says a small number of people have been injured and are being cared for onboard the vessel. Port authorities in the capital Palma say the incident was caused by high winds. Heavy rains have swept across Mallorca over the weekend, and flights from Barcelona were delayed because of the high winds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cruise ship collides with petrol tanker off Mallorca

children.content: A cruise ship has collided with a petrol tanker off the Spanish tourist island of Mallorca.
P
O Cruises says a small number of people have been injured and are being cared for onboard the vessel.
Port authorities in the capital Palma say the incident was caused by high winds.
Heavy rains have swept across Mallorca over the weekend, and flights from Barcelona were delayed because of the high winds.

image.altText: A close up image of drinks from Chatime, with a purple lid.

items.synopsis: Whether it is wage theft, outdated enterprise agreements, or traineeships subsidised by the government, an ominous cloud has hung over the country's labour force for years, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: The Chatime underpayment penalty will send a message to those at the top of the franchising sector

image.altText: Daniel Andrews wears a blue suit and white shirt and frowns while looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Victoria's cancellation of the 2026 regional Commonwealth Games is under scrutiny today, as a Senate inquiry holds hearings in Melbourne. Follow live.

title.children: No attempt made to change Victoria's mind after 'emphatic' cancellation, inquiry hears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In compiling the initial cost estimates, Mr Yates reveals EY was limited by the state government not providing for consultation with councils, the opportunity to visit sites or have access to design work. Senator Colbeck continues to push the representatives to comment on the final costs (which they weren't involved in providing), or detail an example of another project that had a similar capital cost blow out as the 2026 Commonwealth Games. They say they'll take the question on notice, and cite confidentiality obligations to their clients. Senator Henderson points to a figure in the business case referring to $205 million to $215 million to be provided by the federal government. YATES: That was an assumption that was directly given to us (by the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions). HENDERSON: Did the assumption have any basis of fact? YATES: Well, you'd have to ask the department what was the basis of its information … HENDERSON: Well hang on a minute … you're the one preparing the business case, don't you scrutinise the assumptions to be given? Do you ask the question 'was this a committed amount' or 'on what basis are we assuming that we will receive $205 million as a worst case and $215 million as a best case from the federal government?' YATES: That assumption was an assumption that was given to us. HENDERSON: You just take that at face value? You don't query it, you don't question it, you don't say well what's the basis for it? WALKER: We can't answer that question because to do so we might reveal information that's part of cabinet in-confidence. HENDERSON: Oh that's just rubbish! … That is just an absolute cop out. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consultants pushed on assumptions included in business case costing

children.content: In compiling the initial cost estimates, Mr Yates reveals EY was limited by the state government not providing for consultation with councils, the opportunity to visit sites or have access to design work.

Senator Colbeck continues to push the representatives to comment on the final costs (which they weren't involved in providing), or detail an example of another project that had a similar capital cost blow out as the 2026 Commonwealth Games.
They say they'll take the question on notice, and cite confidentiality obligations to their clients.
Senator Henderson points to a figure in the business case referring to $205 million to $215 million to be provided by the federal government.
YATES:
That was an assumption that was directly given to us (by the Department of Jobs, Precincts and Regions).
HENDERSON:
Did the assumption have any basis of fact?
YATES:
Well, you'd have to ask the department what was the basis of its information …
HENDERSON:

Well hang on a minute … you're the one preparing the business case, don't you scrutinise the assumptions to be given? Do you ask the question 'was this a committed amount' or 'on what basis are we assuming that we will receive $205 million as a worst case and $215 million as a best case from the federal government?'
YATES:
That assumption was an assumption that was given to us.
HENDERSON:
You just take that at face value? You don't query it, you don't question it, you don't say well what's the basis for it?
WALKER:
We can't answer that question because to do so we might reveal information that's part of cabinet in-confidence.
HENDERSON:
Oh that's just rubbish! … That is just an absolute cop out.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liberal Senator Richard Colbeck has taken up the baton and accused Labor premiers and the media of talking down the games, saying a Western Australia editorial "disgracefully described it as a second-rate sporting event". He's asked the Commonwealth Games Australia representatives how they felt about the descriptions. PHILLIPS: I think for us it's probably a constant battle … in terms of the Commonwealth Games and something we need to work on is that perception of the games. Mr Phillips pointed forward to Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate's appearance in the afternoon, saying he hoped the benefits would be outlined during his evidence. Senator Colbeck said the last three games had all provided an economic benefit and asked whether Alberta, Canada's reference to costs in not bidding for 2030 damaged the image of the Commonwealth Games. "I think it certainly makes our life difficult ," Mr Phillips said. He said Commonwealth Games Australia has to continue to push the cost-benefit ratio, not just the costs. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boosting perception of Commonwealth Games 'a constant battle'

children.content: Liberal Senator Richard Colbeck has taken up the baton and accused Labor premiers and the media of talking down the games, saying a Western Australia editorial "disgracefully described it as a second-rate sporting event".
He's asked the Commonwealth Games Australia representatives how they felt about the descriptions.
PHILLIPS:
I think for us it's probably
a constant battle
… in terms of the Commonwealth Games and something we need to work on is that perception of the games.
Mr Phillips pointed forward to Gold Coast mayor Tom Tate's appearance in the afternoon, saying he hoped the benefits would be outlined during his evidence.

Senator Colbeck said the last three games had all provided an economic benefit and asked whether Alberta, Canada's reference to costs in not bidding for 2030 damaged the image of the Commonwealth Games.
"I think
it certainly makes our life difficult
," Mr Phillips said.
He said Commonwealth Games Australia has to continue to push the cost-benefit ratio, not just the costs.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Phillips and Mr Houston have told Senator Henderson that neither of them have attempted to talk to the Premier Daniel Andrews or Commonwealth Games Delivery Minister Jacinta Allan after being told of Victoria's decision to pull out of the 2026 event. Mr Phillips agreed Commonwealth Games Australia had already made suggestions in May on how to make the event cheaper and he believed Mr Andrews announcement in July was "fairly emphatic". HENDERSON: Did you attempt to go back and try and put the deal back on track? Say 'look there's a way that we can, we've got some suggestions for you, can you please give us the courtesy of a hearing?' PHILLIPS: No we didn't, Senator, but it was clear by the premier's announcement on the day that that didn't seem to be an option on the table. Reporting by Melissa Brown
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No attempt made to change Victoria's mind after 'emphatic' cancellation

children.content: Mr Phillips and Mr Houston have told Senator Henderson that neither of them have attempted to talk to the Premier Daniel Andrews or Commonwealth Games Delivery Minister Jacinta Allan after being told of Victoria's decision to pull out of the 2026 event.

props.alt: Craig Phillips appears serious, seated as he appears before an inquiry.

children.content: Commonwealth Games Australia CEO Craig Phillips says it was clear Victoria had made up its mind to cancel the Games.
(Parliament of Australia)
Mr Phillips agreed Commonwealth Games Australia had already made suggestions in May on how to make the event cheaper and he believed Mr Andrews announcement in July was "fairly emphatic".
HENDERSON:
Did you attempt to go back and try and put the deal back on track? Say 'look there's a way that we can, we've got some suggestions for you, can you please give us the courtesy of a hearing?'
PHILLIPS:
No we didn't, Senator, but it was clear by the premier's announcement on the day that that didn't seem to be an option on the table.
Reporting by Melissa Brown

image.altText: A close up of a bald man wearing a jumper looking off camera in a snowy field.

title.children: Russia's investigators confirm Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin died in plane crash

title.children: Estranged partner charged over death of Tatiana Dokhotaru who made frantic triple-0 call

items.synopsis: There are concerns backpackers will stop coming to regional WA and leave farmers in the lurch should visa requirements be changed.

title.children: What will happen if Australia scraps the 88-day backpacker visa requirement?

image.altText: Composite of a woman wearing a black top and red jacket, with a collage of photos of sheep.

items.synopsis: Shatha Hamade has spent years going undercover to investigate offshore animal cruelty. She's shared new footage with ABC's 7.30 allegedly showing Australian sheep being sold, handled and slaughtered in breach of Australian rules that were introduced over a decade ago.

title.children: Shatha goes undercover to document animal cruelty in Australia's live export trade. This is what she's found

image.altText: A picture of the Aboriginal flag on a  flagpole

items.synopsis: When Tasmania's wilderness was nominated for World Heritage listing in 1982, a key document said Tasmanian Aboriginal people were "an extinct race of humans". Four decades on, the "offensive and inaccurate" myth has been corrected.

title.children: Tasmanian Aboriginal people, extinct. Thylacine, maybe still out there: 'Offensive' UNESCO document removed

image.altText: An Indigenous man with dreadlocks and a grey goatee standing on a beach

items.synopsis: A First Nations man who is deaf says he learned about the Indigenous Voice to Parliament while attending a dance festival. Advocates say they are concerned about a lack of both Auslan and cultural sign language ahead of the referendum.

title.children: A 'Yes' T-shirt is how this deaf Indigenous man just found out about the Voice referendum

image.altText: A group of people walk along a street with signs bearing the word Yes above them.

items.synopsis: AFL legend Michael Long has begun a 650-kilometre walk to Canberra in support of the Yes vote in the Voice referendum, repeating his historic 2004 journey made to raise the voices of Indigenous communities.

title.children: Last time Michael Long walked to Canberra, he copped violent threats. Now, he wants to bring Australia together

image.altText: Zhang Jiayi poses for a photograph in the street with her parents.

items.synopsis: With her newly founded clothing company struggling amid China's economic downturn, 31-year-old Zhang Jiayi decided to join the trend of young Chinese adults becoming "full-time children".

title.children: Why young Chinese adults are choosing to become 'full-time children'

image.altText: Jim Caviezel stars as Tim Ballard in Sound of Freedom.

items.synopsis: Sound of Freedom has made more money in the US than Mission Impossible — Dead Reckoning, but its factual inaccuracies have some experts worried.

title.children: This controversial anti-sex trafficking film is storming the US box office and it has experts worried

items.synopsis: Twelve years ago the Dunedin council in New Zealand removed shark nets from three beaches and no one has been attacked, questions are being asked about why the same can't happen in NSW.

title.children: NSW beachgoers will be caught in the middle of 'fraught' shark politics this summer

image.altText: Vote yes Indigenous Voice

items.synopsis: Voice supporters believe they need South Australia's backing to get the referendum over the line, but there's scepticism about the proposal among the state's Indigenous community.

title.children: 'It is the most important state': Why South Australia could make or break the Yes campaign

image.altText: A composite image showing Rabaul airport

items.synopsis: In 1994, a volcanic eruption destroyed a thriving town in PNG. Years later, houses have been rebuilt, as scientists watch and wait for the next big blast.

title.children: Peaceful Rabaul was known as the 'pearl of the Pacific'. Then the earth cracked open

image.altText: A mining truck carrying iron ore on a remote mine site.

items.synopsis: Local shares make gains as reporting season continues, and the chief executive of Fortescue leaves after less than six months. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises, Fortescue shares down as boss exits, profit drops

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shares in indebted property developer Evergrande have returned to trade for the first time in nearly a year and a half. And… it's not going well. Hong Kong-listed shares in China Evergrande Group have plunged more than 80 per cent so far this session. According to Reuters, Evergrande would have faced delisting if the suspension had reached 18 months, and that could've jeopardised some of its debt restructuring plans. Other listed entities in the group resumed trade in the past month as well.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares in China's Evergrande plunge more than 80%

children.content: Shares in indebted property developer
Evergrande
have returned to trade for the first time in nearly a year and a half.
And… it's not going well.
Hong Kong-listed
shares in China Evergrande Group have plunged more than 80 per cent
so far this session.
According to Reuters, Evergrande would have faced delisting if the suspension had reached 18 months, and that could've jeopardised some of its debt restructuring plans.
Other listed entities in the group resumed trade in the past month as well.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Retail trade figures for July have just been released by the Bureau of Statistics, and reveal that sales edged higher in July. Retail turnover increased by 0.5 per cent last month, after falling 0.8 per cent in June. Spending on food was flat, while household goods fell. The biggest increases were in department store, clothing & footwear and cafes & restaurants. "The rise in July is a partial reversal of last month's sharp decline in turnover. This was after weaker-than-usual end of financial year sales," ABS head of retail statistics Ben Dorber said. "While there was a rise in July, underlying growth in retail turnover remained subdued. "Cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services turnover grew considerably, despite an overall slowing down in food-related spending in recent months. "The rise in July was boosted by additional spending at catering and takeaway food outlets linked to the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup and school holidays." These figures also don't factor any change in prices. Monthly inflation data will be released on Wednesday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Retail sales edge up in July but remain 'subdued'

children.content: Retail trade figures for July have just been released by the
Bureau of Statistics
, and reveal that sales edged higher in July.
Retail turnover increased by 0.5 per cent last month
, after falling 0.8 per cent in June.
Spending on food was flat, while household goods fell. The biggest increases were in department store, clothing
footwear and cafes
restaurants.
"The rise in July is a partial reversal of last month's sharp decline in turnover. This was after weaker-than-usual end of financial year sales," ABS head of retail statistics Ben Dorber said.
"While there was a rise in July, underlying growth in retail turnover remained subdued.
"Cafes, restaurants and takeaway food services turnover grew considerably, despite an overall slowing down in food-related spending in recent months.
"The rise in July was boosted by additional spending at catering and takeaway food outlets linked to the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup and school holidays."
These figures also don't factor any change in prices. Monthly inflation data will be released on Wednesday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened higher, with the ASX 200 gaining around half a per cent so far. In early trade, 135 stocks have risen on the benchmark index, with the energy, consumer and financials sectors leading the charge. Education, materials and technology are in the red. Fortescue is among the worst performers of the session so far, after announcing a fall in full-year profit and a change in CEO after less than 6 months — the stock is down around 3.3 per cent .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX on the rise, Fortescue shares down

Fortescue

down around 3.3 per cent

items.synopsis: Standard surgery for rheumatoid arthritis could have only further limited Tracy Howlett's movement, so surgeons did something "unconventional" instead.

title.children: Wrist replacement surgery gives Queensland woman who uses Auslan back her 'voice'

image.altText: A storefront with a big yellow sign reading dollar general on top with green grass and trees in front and police man and cars

items.synopsis: The white gunman who shot and killed three black people at a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Florida, was identified as a 21-year-old who bought his guns legally and had no criminal history, local law enforcement says.

title.children: Man who killed three in 'racially motivated' shooting bought guns legally, had no criminal record, Florida police say

image.altText: A wombat walks out of a burrow

items.synopsis: With only 315 of the marsupials left, conservationists are using subsurface mapping to investigate the wombats' burrows in a bid to find potential new habitats for the critically endangered species.

title.children: With just 315 northern hairy-nosed wombats left, conservationists are looking to map their underground homes
